The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs(Previous informed the Cabinet that he had resumed conversa-Ref reference e:Cabinet 52 tions with Sarwat Pasha on the previous Monday. He(27), Con-cliision 11.) had begun by saying that he had been rather disappointment -pointed at Sarwat's first thoughts on his own draft.But before discussing these he v/ould like to knowwhether there was any prospect that, if he and Sarwatreached agreement, Sarwat could secure acceptanceof its terms by Egypt. If there were no suchprospect, Sir Austen Chamberlain thought that itwould be useless and inadvisable to attempt any revision of the draft at this moment. Sarwat had said that the prospect was, he thought, ratherimproved by Zaghloul's death. Zaghloul had to someextent been a prisoner of his own Party, and could probably not have helped nuch in securing the accept-ance of a Treaty even if he had desired to do so.On the whole, therefore, Sarwat thought the situationrather easier. He had spoken about the matter ingeneral terms to see of his colleagues and certain important people in Egypt, but with no details, andhe called Sir Austen's attention to the fact thatthere had been no leakage of information either Inregard to his own draft Treaty or to Sir Austen'scounter draft. Sarwat expressed himself as confident that if he could reach agreement with Sir austen chamberlain he could carry his colleagues in theCabinet, and, if given time, he thought he would beable to gat it accepted by the Legislature. He had,however, no powers to sign a Treaty without obtaining the approval of the Egyptian Cabinet. Sir Austen. . Chamberlain had said that he was in the same .:position, could not sign a Treaty until he had secured the agreement of his colleagues and laid it before Parliament.As regards the draft Treaty,- Sir austen chamberlain had made it clear that it was Impossiblefor him to fix a date for removing the troops from cairo. He could not go beyond a promise to re-examinethe question after ten years, and he had made it clearthat unless by that time the British Government had seen reason to change its view the status quo must continue. As regards the Sudan, the status quo antewas impossible, and no promise could be given as toa change in its status in the future. We could not go back on the situation which had followed from"Mr Ramsay MacDonald*s warning to the Egyptians andthe subsequent events leading up to the murder ofSir Lee Stack. Sarwat, in consequence, had been willing to leave out all mention of the Sudan.Sir Austen had replied that the condominium, asillustrated by the flying of the two Flags, could continue so long as Egypt paid the subsidy. Insome matters Sir Austen had thought It might bepossible to meet Sarwat, either by omitting particu-lar word3 from the draft Treaty or by giving explana-tions. He had arranged for discussions betweenSarwat, Sir Cecil Hurst and Mr Murray, in regard todetails and the form of the Treaty which Sarwatmight be able to accept. That was the presentsituation. As soon as he had received reports ofthe above conversations the Secretary of state proposed to discuss the matter first with his department and Lord Lloyd, and then to report tothe,"Cabinet Committee. The Cabinet had before their a Memorandum bythe Secretary of State for India (Paper C.P.-359 (2*?)asking for the concurrence of the Cabinet in thefollowing alterations in the proposals agreed to atthe meeting referred to in the margin:-(i) That the names of the commisioners should be announced shortly and thatthe Commission should pay a preliminaryvisit to India in January to march next and not defer its visit until theautumn o^ 1928.(ii) That legislation in the form of a two-Clause Bill (a copy of which isattached to the Secretary of State'note), should be passed at theearliest possible date in November,to enable the Commission to be ants-dated .(iii) "hat an announcement should be madehare in Parliament, and simultaneously in India, of the agreed programmecontemplated for the Commission andthe names of its members, and thatthis announcement should be followedimmediately by the introduction ofthe Bill referred to abo"e.A copy of the announcement which theViceroy proposed to make in India onthe SJiwe day as the announcement ismade In Parliament here is attachedto the Memorandum.The Secretary of State for India made a state-ment in regard to the above proposals, in the cottrseof which he communicated to th? Cabinet the names of the Chairman and members of the Commission, whohad been agreed to by Lord Peel, Lord Winterton and himself, and who had acoepte d to serve. The names of the- representatives of the Labour Party, Lord BIrken-head added, had been approved by the Leader of that party.The Cabinet were given to understand that thePrime Minister had communicated with the Chief Whipon this subject with a view to the necessary Parlia-mentary time being given for the passage of the legislation, and that the Chief '-'hip had notifiedthe Secretary that morning that he did not wish tobe summoned to the Cabinet in this connection.The Cabinet approved the proposalsof the Secretary of State for india as set forth above. The Cabinet had before them the Report.of aCabinet Committee (Paper C.P.-253 (27)) in regardto the Report of the Crown Proceedings Committee,containing the following recommendations:-(i) That In the event of the draftBrussels Convention on the Immunityof State Owned Ships being amended to the satisfaction of the BritishGovernment it may be necessary tointroduce legislation to ratify theConvention in 1928.(ii) That the question of giving power tothe Courts to deal at their discretionwith the costs of proceedings by and against the Crown be considered inconnection with any Judicature bill which, may be introduced next year,(iii) That as regards the remaining pro-posalsof the Crown Proceedings Bill,while there would appear to be no possibility of Introducing legislation on the lines of the provisions of thedra^t Bill in the present Parliament,the question might be further con-sidered by the Cabinet towards the close of 1928.After hearing a statement from the LordChancellor -The Cabinet approved the above recommendations . The Secretary of State for Air consulted theCabinet in regard to an application from a British.armaments firm to build fifty "Gorcock" fighteraeroplanes for the Government of Soviet Russia,This was a type of machine which the Air ministry had rejected. The machines would be "fighters" andnot "bombers". Their range was limited to 100 miles,and they were therefore of defensive rather thanoffensive value, and could form no danger to theBritish Empire either in Afghanistan or elsewhere.The order would take two years to carry out. Ifrelations should become strained in the intervalmeans could be found for holding up the order.Spare parts, of course, would be obtained in Great -Britain. The Air Staff considered that the fulfilment of this order ought to be sanctioned.The Cabinet agreed that the aboveorder should be sanctioned. 2, Whitehall Gardens, S.W.1,November 2, 1927.-9-TRADE OUTLOOK. 7. The President of the Board of Trade informed the Cabinet that, at his usual monthly meeting withhis Advisory Council, the reports of British trade had been rather less discouraging than at recentprevious meetings.
